page.title: 7.14.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will interpret equations and graphs of quadratic functions in terms of the situations they represent. Additionally, you will use your analyses to solve problems and to compare quadratic functions given in different representations.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain how a quadratic equation and its graph relate to a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.14.1: Evaluating Quadratic Functions in the Real World
  • 7.14.2: Interpreting a Functional Relationship Between Two Quantities
    • 7.14.2: Self Check
    • 7.14.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.14.3: Analyzing Functions Using Different Representations
    • 7.14.3: Self Check
    • 7.14.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.14.4: Using Quadratic Functions to Solve Problems
  • 7.14.5: Identifying Key Features of Graphed Functions

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.14.6: Practice
  • 7.14.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.14.1: Evaluating Quadratic Functions in the Real World
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

The height, in inches, of a frog's jump is modeled by the equation \(h(t)=60t-75t^2\), where the time \(t\), after the frog jumps, is measured in seconds.

  1. For \(h(t)=60t-75t^2\):
    1. Find \(h(0)\).

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0

The correct answer is 0.

    1. Find \(h(0.8)\).

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0

The correct answer is 0.


  1. What do these values of \(h(0)\) and \(h(0.8)\) mean in terms of the frog's jump?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

They mean that the frog is on the ground when \(t=0\) (before jumping) and when \(t=0.8\) (when the frog lands on the ground).


  1. After it jumped, how much time passed, in seconds, before the frog reached its maximum height?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0.4 seconds

The correct answer is 0.4 seconds.


  1. Explain how you know this is the time the frog reached the maximum height.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The frog reached its maximum height at \(t=0.4\), as that is the halfway point of the jump. If we graph the function, the vertex of the graph will have a horizontal coordinate (\(t\)-coordinate) of 0.4.

page.title: 7.14.2: Interpreting a Functional Relationship Between Two Quantities
page.contents:
Student Activity

The equation \(h(t)=2+23.7t-4.9t^2\) represents the height of a pumpkin that is catapulted up in the air as a function of time, \(t\), in seconds. The height is measured in meters above ground. The pumpkin is shot up at a vertical velocity of 23.7 meters per second.


  1. What do you think the 2 in the equation \(h(t)=2+23.7t-4.9t^2\) tells us in this situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The 2 tells us the pumpkin is 2 meters above ground before it is launched.


  1. What do you think the \(-4.9t^2\) in the equation \(h(t)=2+23.7t-4.9t^2\) tells us in this situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Answer: The \(-4.9t^2\) shows the height lost due to gravity (like the \(-16t^2\) in the cannonball problem).


  1. If we graph the equation, will the graph open upward or downward? Why?

Correct! The graph would open downward. The height starts at 2 meters and then increases as the pumpkin is shot up, and eventually, it decreases as the pumpkin falls back to the ground

Incorrect. The correct answer is downward. The graph would open downward. The height starts at 2 meters and then increases as the pumpkin is shot up, and eventually, it decreases as the pumpkin falls back to the ground.

  1. Think about where the vertical intercept would be. What is the \(y\)-value of that vertical intercept?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! The vertical intercept would be at \((0,2)\), because when \(t\) is 0, the height is 2 meters.

The correct answer is 2. The vertical intercept would be at \((0,2)\), because when \(t\) is 0, the height is 2 meters.


  1. What about the horizontal intercepts?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The horizontal intercepts are hard to tell without graphing or having the equation in factored form. One of them will be located around \((5,0)\) because substituting 5 for \(t\) gives a height of -2 meters, which is pretty close to 0.



  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Graph the equation \(h(t)=2+23.7t-4.9t^2\).


Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:


  1. Now that you have graphed the equation, answer questions a–c using the graph.
    1. What is the vertical intercept and what does this point mean in our catapulted pumpkin situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The vertical intercept is \((0,2)\). It tells us that the pumpkin's initial position is 2 meters above ground.


    1. What are the horizontal intercepts and what do these points mean in our catapulted pumpkin situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The graph intersects the horizontal axis around -0.08 and 4.9. The positive horizontal intercept tells us that the pumpkin hits the ground after about 4.9 seconds. The negative intercept doesn't have any meaning here since the time cannot be negative in this case.


    1. What is the vertex of the parabola and what does this point mean in our catapulted pumpkin situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The vertex is at approximately \((2.4,30.7)\). It tells us that the pumpkin reaches its maximum height of about 30.7 meters around 2.4 seconds after being fired.




Extending Your Thinking

What approximate vertical velocity would this pumpkin need for it to stay in the air for about 10 seconds? (Assume that it is still shot from 2 meters above the ground and that the effect of gravity pulling it down is the same.)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

If \(h(t)=2+bt−4.9t^2\) takes the value 0 when \(t\) is close to 10, this means that \(2+10b−490\) is close to zero. That means we want \(b\) to be 48.8. The pumpkin needs to be shot in the air at 48.8 meters per second.

page.title: 7.14.2: Self Check
page.contents:
The function that gives the height, \(h\), in feet of a cannonball \(t\) seconds after the ball leaves the cannon is graphed below.

What is the point \((10, 1,600)\) and what does it mean in this situation?

answer.answer_text: \(Y\)-intercept, the highest height the cannonball reaches
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(y\)-intercept occurs when \(x=0\) and represents the height the cannonball is launched from. The answer is maximum height, the highest height the cannonball reaches.

answer.answer_text: Maximum height, the height the cannonball was launched
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The cannonball travels higher than where it is launched. The answer is maximum height, the highest height the cannonball reaches.

answer.answer_text: Maximum height, the highest height the cannonball reaches
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The point is at the peak of the graph, or the maximum height. It tells how high the cannonball goes before coming back down.

answer.answer_text: \(Y\)-intercept, the height the cannonball was launched
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(y\)-intercept occurs when \(x=0\). You are describing the point where \(x=10\) and \(y\) is at the peak of the graph. The answer is maximum height, the highest height the cannonball reaches.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.14.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
The Meaning of Values on a Graph

Let’s say a tennis ball is hit straight up in the air, and its height in feet above the ground is modeled by the equation \(f(t)=4+12t−16t^2\) where \(t\) represents the time in seconds after the ball is hit. Here is a graph that represents the function, from the time the tennis ball was hit until the time it reached the ground.

In the graph, we can see some information we already know, and some new information:

  • The 4 in the equation means the graph of the function intersects the vertical axis at 4. It shows that the tennis ball was 4 feet off the ground at \(t=0\), when it was hit.
  • The horizontal intercept is \((1,0)\). It tells us that the tennis ball hit the ground 1 second after it was hit.
  • The vertex of the graph is at approximately \((0.4,6.3)\). This means that about 0.4 second after the ball was hit, it reached the maximum height of about 6.3 feet.

The equation can be written in factored form as \(f(t)=(-16t−4)(t−1)\). From this form, we can see that the zeros of the function are \(t=1\) and \(t=-14\). The negative zero, -14, is not meaningful in this situation because the time before the ball was hit is irrelevant.

Try It: The Meaning of Values on a Graph

An object is thrown upward from a height of 5 feet with a velocity of 60 feet per second. Its height h(t) in feet after \(t\) seconds is modeled by the function \(h(t)=5+60t-16t^2\) and graphed below.

What is the value of the vertical intercept (\(y\)-intercept) and what does it mean in the function?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine the \(y\)-intercept:

The vertical intercept, or \(y\)-intercept, is where the graph crosses the \(y\)-axis. It occurs when \(x=0\). You can also identify the \(y\)-intercept by looking at the constant in the function. This occurs at \(y=5\). The point is (0,5). The \(y\)-intercept represents the initial height. It means the object is thrown from 5 feet above the ground.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.14.3: Analyzing Functions Using Different Representations
page.contents:
Activity

Here is a graph that represents the height of a baseball, \(h\), in feet as a function of time, \(t\), in seconds after it was hit by Player A.

The function \(g\) defined by \(g(t)=(-16t−1)(t−4)\) also represents the height in feet of a baseball \(t\) seconds after it was hit by Player B. Without graphing function \(g\), answer the following questions and explain or show how you know.

  1. Which player's baseball stayed in flight longer?

Correct! Player A's baseball stayed in flight longer. The zeros of function \(g\) are 4 and \(-\frac{1}{16}\). The negative zero doesn't have any meaning in this situation. A zero in this situation means the time when the baseball has a height of 0 (or when it hits the ground). For Player B, this happened when \(t=4\) or 4 seconds after it was hit. Player A's baseball hit the ground a little over 5 seconds after it was hit.

Incorrect. The correct answer is: Player A's baseball stayed in flight longer. The zeros of function \(g\) are 4 and \(-\frac{1}{16}\). The negative zero doesn't have any meaning in this situation. A zero in this situation means the time when the baseball has a height of 0 (or when it hits the ground). For Player B, this happened when \(t=4\) or 4 seconds after it was hit. Player A's baseball hit the ground a little over 5 seconds after it was hit.

  1. Which player's baseball reached a greater maximum height?

Correct! Player A's baseball reached a greater maximum height. From the graph for Player A, it looks like the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is around 105 feet. For Player B, the vertex of the graph has a \(t\)-coordinate of about 2 (halfway between -116 and 4). We can find g(2) to estimate the height at that point. \(g(2)=(-16(2)−1)(2−4)=(-33)(-2)=66\), so the highest point of Player B's baseball was around 66 feet.

The correct answer is: Player A's baseball reached a greater maximum height. From the graph for Player A, it looks like the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is around 105 feet. For Player B, the vertex of the graph has a \(t\)-coordinate of about 2 (halfway between -116 and 4). We can find g(2) to estimate the height at that point. \(g(2)=(-16(2)−1)(2−4)=(-33)(-2)=66\), so the highest point of Player B's baseball was around 66 feet.


  1. Based on the graph, what is the approximate height, in feet, of Player A’s baseball when hit? How do you know?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

We can look at the \(y\)-intercept of the graph, and it looks like the \(y\)-coordinate is about 5.

  1. What is the height, in feet, of Player B’s baseball when hit?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! 4 feet. Find the height when \(t=0\). \(g(0)=(-16(0)−1)(0−4)=(-1)(-4)=4\), so it was hit at 4 feet.

The correct answer is 4 feet. Find the height when \(t=0\). \(g(0)=(-16(0)−1)(0−4)=(-1)(-4)=4\), so it was hit at 4 feet.



Video: Comparing Quadratic Functions

Watch the following video to learn more about comparing quadratic functions in different forms.

page.title: 7.14.3: Self Check
page.contents:
The functions describing the time that baseballs stayed in the air, in seconds, that four baseball players hit are below.

  • \(f(t)=(-16t-1)(t-5)\)
  • \(g(t)=(-16t-1)(t-10)\)
  • \(h(t)=(t-7)(-16t-1)\)
  • \(p(t)=(-8t-1)(2t-5)\)

Which function represents the ball that stayed in the air the longest?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ball traveled 5 seconds. There are other choices that stayed in the air longer. The answer is \(g(t)=(-16t-1)(t-10)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Since \(t-10=0\) at \(t=10\), the ball travels 10 seconds. This is the farthest ball.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ball traveled 7 seconds. There is another choice that stayed in the air longer. The answer is \(g(t)=(-16t-1)(t-10)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The zero is at \(x=52\) seconds. There are other choices that stayed in the air longer. The answer is \(g(t)=(-16t-1)(t-10)\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure

page.title: 7.14.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Comparing the Graphs and Equations of Quadratic Functions

Jai kicks a football. The graph that represents the height of the football, \(h\), as a function of time, in seconds, is below.

Kellan kicks a football and the height in feet, \(h\), is represented by the function \(h(t)=(-16t-1)(t-6)\).

Which player’s football stayed in the air longer?

Jai’s football landed after 4 seconds since the zero is at \(x=4\). The other zero, where \(x\) is negative, does not make sense in this problem.

Looking at the function of Kellan’s ball, find the zeros by setting each factor equal to zero.

  • \(-16t-1=0\) becomes \(t=-116\). A negative time does not make sense in this problem.
  • \(t-6=0\) becomes \(t=6\).

Kellan’s ball was in the air for 6 seconds, so his ball stayed in the air 2 seconds longer than Jai’s.

Try It: Comparing the Graphs and Equations of Quadratic Functions


Using the same information above, which player’s football reached a higher height?

Write down your answer, then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine whose ball went higher:

Looking at the graph of Jai’s football, his football went about 70 feet high.

Step 1
For Kellan’s football, find the vertex.
The vertex is halfway between the zeros. Since -116 is near 0 and the other \(x\)-intercept is at 6, we can use 3 as an estimate for the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex.

Step 2
Substitute this into the function:
\(h(t)=(-16(3)-1)((3)-6)=(-49)(-3)=147\).

Kellan’s ball went 147 feet into the air so his football went higher.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.14.4: Using Quadratic Functions to Solve Problems
page.contents:
Optional Activity

Your teacher will give you either a problem card or a data card. Do not show or read your card to your partner.

If your teacher gives you the data card:

  1. Silently read the information on your card.
  2. Ask your partner, "What specific information do you need?" and wait for your partner to ask for information. Only give information that is on your card. (Do not figure out anything for your partner!)
  3. Before telling your partner the information, ask, "Why do you need to know (that piece of information)?"
  4. Read the problem card and solve the problem independently.
  5. Share the data card and discuss your reasoning.
  6. Pause here so your teacher can review your work. Ask your teacher for a new set of cards and repeat the activity (steps 1–5) for the next problem, trading roles with your partner.
  7. When you and your partner have solved both problems, enter your answers to the questions below.

If your teacher gives you the problem card:

  1. Silently read your card and think about what information you need to answer the question.
  2. Ask your partner for the specific information that you need.
  3. Explain to your partner how you are using the information to solve the problem.
  4. When you have enough information, share the problem card with your partner, and solve the problem independently.
  5. Read the data card and discuss your reasoning.
  6. Pause here so your teacher can review your work. Ask your teacher for a new set of cards and repeat the activity (steps 1–5) for the next problem, trading roles with your partner.
  7. When you and your partner have solved both problems, enter your answers to the questions below.

The following are copies of the four cards you used to solve each of the problems. Choose the card that has the matching information you used to solve each problem.

Problem Card 1

Kiran was timing the flight of his toy rocket.  It launches straight up from the ground.

  1. At how many seconds after launch did the rocket reach the highest point?
  2. The rocket was 8.8 feet above ground on the way up and again on the way down. How many seconds passed between the two times it was 8.8 feet above ground?
Problem Card 2
  1. How many feet above the ground did the toy rocket go?
  2. Jada suggested they put Kiran’s rocket on a platform and then launch the rocket from there. Will the rocket reach 20 feet above ground at its highest point?
Data Card 1
  • The stopwatch showed 0 seconds when the toy rocket blasted off from the ground.
  • It landed back on the ground when the stopwatch showed 1.6 seconds. 
  • The second time the rocket reached 8.8 feet, the stopwatch showed 1.1 seconds. 
Data Card 2
  • The equation modeling the the height of Kiran’s toy rocket was y=-16x(x-16).
  • \(y\) represents the height above ground in feet, and \(x\) represents time in seconds. 
  • The platform is 4 feet above ground.
  1. Card A

    2. Kiran was timing the flight of his toy rocket. It launches straight up from the ground.

    1. At how many seconds after launch did the rocket reach the highest point?
    2. The rocket was 8.8 feet above ground on the way up and again on the way down. How many seconds passed between the two times it was 8.8 feet above ground?

Choose the card with the information you used to solve the problem on Card A.

Card B
  1. How many feet above the ground did the toy rocket go?
  2. Jada suggested they put Kiran’s rocket on a platform and then launch the rocket from there. Will the rocket reach 20 feet above ground at its highest point?
Card C
  • The stopwatch showed 0 seconds when the toy rocket blasted off from the ground.
  • It landed back on the ground when the stopwatch showed 1.6 seconds.
  • The second time the rocket reached 8.8 feet, the stopwatch showed 1.1 seconds.
Card D
  • The equation modeling the the height of Kiran’s toy rocket was \(y=-16x(x-16)\).
  • \(y\) represents the height above ground in feet, and \(x\) represents time in seconds.
  • The platform is 4 feet above ground.

Discuss the different card choices with your partner.

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Card C is Data Card 1. It contains the information needed to solve Problem Card 1.

Card C
  • The stopwatch showed 0 seconds when the toy rocket blasted off from the ground.
  • It landed back on the ground when the stopwatch showed 1.6 seconds.
  • The second time the rocket reached 8.8 feet, the stopwatch showed 1.1 seconds.
  1. Card B
    1. How many feet above the ground did the toy rocket go?
    2. Jada suggested they put Kiran’s rocket on a platform and then launch the rocket from there. Will the rocket reach 20 feet above ground at its highest point?

Choose the card with the information you used to solve the problem on Card B.

Card A

Kiran was timing the flight of his toy rocket. It launches straight up from the ground.

  1. At how many seconds after launch did the rocket reach the highest point?
  2. The rocket was 8.8 feet above ground on the way up and again on the way down. How many seconds passed between the two times it was 8.8 feet above ground?
Card C
  • The stopwatch showed 0 seconds when the toy rocket blasted off from the ground.
  • It landed back on the ground when the stopwatch showed 1.6 seconds.
  • The second time the rocket reached 8.8 feet, the stopwatch showed 1.1 seconds.
Card D
  • The equation modeling the the height of Kiran’s toy rocket was \(y=-16x(x-16)\).
  • \(y\) represents the height above ground in feet, and \(x\) represents time in seconds.
  • The platform is 4 feet above ground.

Discuss the different card choices with your partner.

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Card D is Data Card 2. It contains the information needed to solve Problem Card 2.

Card D
  • The equation modeling the the height of Kiran’s toy rocket was \(y=-16x(x-16)\).
  • \(y\) represents the height above ground in feet, and \(x\) represents time in seconds.
  • The platform is 4 feet above ground.

page.title: 7.14.5: Identifying Key Features of Graphed Functions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The equation \(y=(-16t−2)(t−1)\) represents the height in feet of a beach ball thrown by a child as a function of time, \(t\), in seconds.

  1. Since the equation is in factored form, we can tell that the graph intersects the horizontal axis at two points. Use this information to find the zeros of the function. Explain or show your reasoning.
    1. Find one of the zeros of the functions using \((-16t−2)\).

Enter your answer here. 

Correct! -0.125 or \(-\frac{1}{8}\). From the factored form, we can tell that the graph intersects the horizontal axis at \(t=-0.125\) or \(-\frac{1}{8}\). The zero of the function is the same value.

The correct answer is -0.125 or \(-\frac{1}{8}\). From the factored form, we can tell that the graph intersects the horizontal axis at \(t=-0.125\) or \(-\frac{1}{8}\). The zero of the function is the same value.


    1. Find one of the zeros of the functions using \((t−1)\).

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1. From the factored form, we can tell that the graph intersects the horizontal axis at t=1. The zero of the function is the same value.

The correct answer is 1. From the factored form, we can tell that the graph intersects the horizontal axis at t=1. The zero of the function is the same value.

  1. What do the zeros tell us in this situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The zeros mean the time in seconds when the ball is on the ground.

  1. Are both zeros meaningful?

Correct! No. Only one of them is meaningful. The negative zero doesn't mean anything here.

Incorrect. The correct answer is No. Only one of them is meaningful. The negative zero doesn't mean anything here.


  1. From what height, in feet, is the beach ball thrown? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

2. The height when \(t=0\) is \((-16(0)−2)(0−1)=(-2)(-1)=2\). If you graph the function, the graph shows a y-intercept of \((0,2)\).

page.title: 7.14.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Here are graphs of functions \(f\) and \(g\).

Each represents the height of an object being launched into the air as a function of time.

    1. Which object was launched from a higher point?

Correct! The object represented by function \(g\) because its y-intercept is above the y-intercept of the graph of \(f\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The object represented by function \(g\) because its \(y\)-intercept is above the \(y\)-intercept of the graph of \(f\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which object reached a higher point?

Correct! The object represented by function \(f\) because the vertex is higher.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The object represented by function \(f\) because the vertex is higher. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which object was launched with the greater upward velocity?

Correct! The object represented by function \(f\) because the “slope” near the \(y\)-intercept is greater. It increases in height much more quickly than the other object.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The object represented by function \(f\) because the “slope” near the \(y\)-intercept is greater. It increases in height much more quickly than the other object. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which object landed last?

Correct! The object represented by function \(g\) because the positive \(x\)-intercept of its graph is to the right of the positive \(x\)-intercept of the graph of \(f\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The object represented by function \(g\) because the positive \(x\)-intercept of its graph is to the right of the positive \(x\)-intercept of the graph of \(f\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The function \(h\) given by \(h(t)=(1−t)(8+16t)\) models the height of a ball in feet, \(t\) seconds after it was thrown.
    1. Find one of the zeros of the functions using \((8+16t)\).

Enter your answer here:

Correct! -0.5. From the factored form, we can tell that the graph intersects the horizontal axis at \(t=-0.5\). The zero of the function is the same value.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.14.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is -0.5. From the factored form, we can tell that the graph intersects the horizontal axis at \(t=-0.5\). The zero of the function is the same value. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Find one of the zeros of the functions using \((1-t)\).

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1. From the factored form, we can tell that the graph intersects the horizontal axis at \((1-t)\). The zero of the function is the same value.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.14.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 1. From the factored form, we can tell that the graph intersects the horizontal axis at \((1-t)\). The zero of the function is the same value. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What do the zeros tell us in this situation?

Correct! The positive zero means the time, in seconds, when the basketball is on the ground or hits the ground.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.14.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The positive zero means the time, in seconds, when the basketball is on the ground or hits the ground. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Are both zeros meaningful?

Correct! No. Only the positive zero is meaningful. It tells us the ball hits the ground after 1 second.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.14.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

Incorrect. The correct answer is No. Only the positive zero is meaningful. It tells us the ball hits the ground after 1 second. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. From what height, in feet, is the ball thrown?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 8 feet. When \((1−t)(8+16t)\) is rewritten in standard form it is \(8+8t−16t^2\). The constant term (which corresponds to the \(y\)-intercept) tells us the height of the basketball when \(t=0\) or when it is launched.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.14.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 8 feet. When \((1−t)(8+16t)\) is rewritten in standard form it is \(8+8t−16t^2\). The constant term (which corresponds to the \(y\)-intercept) tells us the height of the basketball when \(t=0\) or when it is launched. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. When, in seconds, does the ball reach its highest point?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! 0.25 seconds. Graphing \(h\) shows the maximum point at (0.25,9). Or, you could recognize that 0.25 is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex because it is halfway between the two zeros, -0.5 and 1.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.14.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 0.25 seconds. Graphing \(h\) shows the maximum point at (0.25,9). Or, you could recognize that 0.25 is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex because it is halfway between the two zeros, -0.5 and 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How high, in feet, does the ball go?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 9 feet. Graphing \(h\) shows the maximum point at (0.25,9). Or, you could recognize that 0.25 is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex because it is halfway between the two zeros, -0.5 and 1. Then evaluate the function at 0.25 to get a height of 9.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.14.3–7.14.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 9 feet. Graphing \(h\) shows the maximum point at (0.25,9). Or, you could recognize that 0.25 is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex because it is halfway between the two zeros, -0.5 and 1. Then evaluate the function at 0.25 to get a height of 9. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The height in feet of a thrown football is modeled by the equation \(f(t)=6+30t−16t^2\), where time \(t\) is measured in seconds.
    1. Which term in the equation describes how many feet above the ground the football was thrown?

Correct! The football was thrown from 6 feet above the ground.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.14.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the constant term 6. The football was thrown from 6 feet above the ground. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which term in the equation describes the initial upward velocity of the football in feet per second?

Correct! The initial upward velocity of the football was 30 feet per second.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.14.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the linear term \(30t\). The initial upward velocity of the football was 30 feet per second. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How does the squared term \(-16t^2\) affect the value of the function \(f\)?

Correct! The squared term decreases the value of the function because the values of \(16t^2\) are being subtracted from \(6+30t\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.14.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The squared term decreases the value of the function because the values of \(16t^2\) are being subtracted from \(6+30t\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What does this term \(−16t^2\) reveal about the situation?

Correct! The influence of gravity pulling the ball down to the ground.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.14.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The influence of gravity pulling the ball down to the ground. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The height in feet of an arrow is modeled by the equation \(h(t)=(1+2t)(18−8t)\), where \(t\) is seconds after the arrow is shot.
    1. At what time, in seconds, does the arrow hit the ground?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! The positive zero is 2.25 because \((18−8t)\) is equal to zero when \(t=2.25\). The zeros mean the times, in seconds, when the arrow is on the ground. Only the positive zero makes sense. The negative zero would represent a time before the arrow was launched.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.14.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 2.25. The positive zero is 2.25 because \((18−8t)\) is equal to zero when \(t=2.25\). The zeros mean the times, in seconds, when the arrow is on the ground. Only the positive zero makes sense. The negative zero would represent a time before the arrow was launched. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. At what height, in feet, is the arrow shot?

Enter your answer here. 

Correct! 18 feet. When the arrow is shot, \(t\) is 0 and h(0)=(1+2⋅0)(18−8⋅0)=(1)(18)=18.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.14.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 18 feet. When the arrow is shot, \(t\) is 0 and \(h(0)=(1+2⋅0)(18−8⋅0)=(1)(18)=18\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. Two objects are launched into the air.

The height, in feet, of Object A is given by the equation \(f(t)=4+32t−16t^2\).

The height, in feet, of Object B is given by the equation \(g(t)=2.5+40t−16^2\).

In both functions, \(t\) is seconds after launch.

    1. Which object was launched from a greater height?

Correct! Object A. The objects are launched when \(t=0\). \(f(0)=4+32⋅0−16(0)2=4\) and \(g(0)=2.5+40⋅0−16(0)2=2.5\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Object A. The objects are launched when \(t=0\). \(f(0)=4+32⋅0−16(0)2=4\) and \(g(0)=2.5+40⋅0−16(0)2=2.5\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which object was launched with a greater upward velocity?

Correct! Object B.The coefficient of \(t\) gives the upward velocity and 40 is greater than 32.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Object B. The coefficient of \(t\) gives the upward velocity and 40 is greater than 32. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.14.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain how a quadratic equation and its graph relate to a situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.14.1: Evaluating Quadratic Functions in the Real World
    • In this activity, you found the meaning of values in a frog’s jump such as maximum height.
  • 7.14.2: Interpreting a Functional Relationship Between Two Quantities
    • In this activity, you found values in a graph and interpreted their meanings based on the situation graphed.
    • 7.14.2: Self Check
    • 7.14.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.14.3: Analyzing Functions Using Different Representations
    • In this activity, you compared the heights of two baseballs hit by using a graph of one baseball player and the function of another.
    • 7.14.3: Self Check
    • 7.14.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.14.4: Using Quadratic Functions to Solve Problems
    • In this optional activity, you determined the information you would need to answer questions about the launch of a toy rocket.
  • 7.14.5: Identifying Key Features of Graphed Functions
    • In this activity, you used an equation to determine the zeros of an equation and the height from which a beach ball was thrown.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.14.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
